title: How to watch Chiefs-Broncos Week 17: live stream, start time and more
description: Everything you need to know to watch Kansas City play Denver on Thursday.
fullText:
Merry Christmas, Chiefs Kingdom!

On Thursday, the (6-9) Kansas City Chiefs will host the (12-3) Denver Broncos on GEHA Field at Arrowhead Stadium for the nightcap of an NFL triple-header to start Week 17. Kickoff is scheduled for 7:15 p.m. Arrowhead Time on Amazon Prime Video; it will be locally available on KSHB-41.

Coming off four consecutive losses that eliminated them from the playoffs, the Chiefs will have a first-time starting quarterback playing on the short week: quarterback Chris Oladokun. He led the team to all nine points scored in the loss to the Tennessee Titans in Week 16.

With two games remaining, the Broncos are in the lead for the AFC West. However, the loss to the Jacksonville Jaguars last week allowed the Los Angeles Chargers an opportunity to overtake Denver in Week 18, regardless of whether Kansas City can pull an upset off or not.

There will be no winter wonderland during this Christmas game; the temperature could reach 60¬∞ on the holiday.

Location: GEHA Field at Arrowhead Stadium, Kansas City, Missouri

Game time: 7:15 p.m. Arrowhead Time, Thursday, December 25, 2025

Weather forecast: Cloudy and 59¬∞ with winds SSE at 7 mph

Matchup history: 72-58 Chiefs (regular season)

Odds: Broncos -13.5, per FanDuel Sportsbook

Officials: Referee Bill Vinovich (52), umpire Scott Walker (11), down judge Dale Keller (9), line judge Tripp Sutter (37), field judge Aaron Santi (50), side judge Jimmy Buchanan (86), back judge Todd Prukop (30), replay official Chad Wakefield and replay assistant Jim Van Geffen

Pageantry: Colors: Leawood Police Department Honor Guard. National Anthem: Brianne Yancey and Mikaela Ayira. Drum Deck Honoree: Trent Green. Spirit Leader: Major Callie Cooper

Television broadcast: with Al Michaels, Kirk Herbstreit and Kaylee Hartung on KSHB (NBC/41-Kansas City) and (ABC/7-Denver)

Online Stream: Fubo.TV, Twitch (computers, mobile devices only)

Chiefs radio broadcast: with Mitch Holthus, Danan Hughes and Josh Klingler on KFNZ (96.5 FM and 610 AM-Kansas City), WDAF (106.5 FM-Kansas City), Chiefs Mobile App and Chiefs Radio Network affiliates

Chiefs Spanish radio broadcast: with Oscar Monterroso, Hannah Bassham and Adan Manzano on the Audacy app (‚ÄúChiefs en Espa√±ol‚Äù), KSSA (105.9 FM-Garden City, Kansas) and KSSM (1470 AM-Liberal, Kansas), Chiefs Mobile App, Tico-Sports.com and NFL+

Broncos radio broadcast: with Dave Logan, Rick Lewis and Susie Wargin on KOA (850 AM-Denver) and¬†Broncos Radio Network affiliates

SiriusXM broadcast: Channel 226

Enemy SB Nation site: Mile High Report

Parking passes: All parking passes must be purchased in advance at www.Chiefs.com; payments will not be accepted at the parking toll gates.

Cashless Arrowhead: All concession stands and retail points of sale are completely cashless. In addition to traditional scan and chip reader options for credit/debit cards, all fixed points of sale offer mobile tap or scan payment options, including Chiefs Pay, Apple Pay, Google Pay and Samsung Pay. In-stadium hawkers and vendors are credit card only.

Clear bags, permitted items: The NFL‚Äôs clear bag policy is in place for all events at GEHA Field at Arrowhead Stadium. Fans can visit www.Chiefs.com/stadium/clearbag for important information on the clear bag policy and a complete list of permitted and prohibited items. Guests will enter the stadium through CEIA OPENGATE security screening technology. As guests approach the stadium, they should keep items in their pockets and/or clear bags as they pass through the advanced screening devices while following the direction of security personnel. All fans should keep moving through the screening gates at a normal pace, as there is no need to wait for the person in front or to stop unless otherwise directed.

COVID-19: Masks are no longer required in indoor spaces. But per Kansas City, Missouri Health Department recommendation, masks are encouraged. Fans should stay home if they are sick, showing COVID-19 symptoms or have been in close contact with anyone who has tested positive for COVID-19. If you become ill and can‚Äôt attend the game, you can resell or transfer your tickets.

title: Report ‚Äì Inter Milan Contemplating Shock January Swoop For Homesick Liverpool Winger
description: Liverpool outcast Federico Chiesa could reportedly make a long-awaited return to Serie A, with Inter Milan emerging as potential suitors.According to Alfio Musmarra via FCInter1908, the Nerazzurri are...
fullText:
Liverpool outcast Federico Chiesa could reportedly make a long-awaited return to Serie A, with Inter Milan emerging as potential suitors.

According to Alfio Musmarra via FCInter1908, the Nerazzurri are pondering an audacious bid for the Italian winger.

It‚Äôs no secret that the San Siro giants crave a skilled winger after losing Denzel Dumfries to a long-term injury.

Furthermore, Luis Henrique has failed to convince Cristian Chivu in the first half of the season.

As a result, Inter could dip back into the market to address the wingback emergency.

DORTUMUN, GERMANY ‚Äì JUNE 28: Federico Chiesa of Italy departs from Dortumund for Berlin on June 28, 2024 in Dortumund, Germany. (Photo by Claudio Villa/Getty Images for FIGC)

Reduced to playing second fiddle to Mohamed Salah and Cody Gakpo, Chiesa has been at the bottom of the pecking order at Liverpool.

Indeed, the former Juventus star has accumulated just 151 minutes in the Premier League this season.

Despite his limited first-team opportunities, he has scored two goals and managed one assist.

However, a player of Chiesa‚Äôs quality doesn‚Äôt deserve to sit on the bench.

title: Bo Nix Odds, Projections & SGP for Thursday Night Football

fullText:

title: Missouri teen makes history for tournament bass fishing
description: The water on Truman Lake was colder and muddier than normal this April, making for some tough fishing conditions. Luke Karg, of House Springs, had one last shot before graduating to win the Missouri TBF High School Trail Super Tournament for bass fishing ‚Äì which he and his then 16-year-old fishing partner, A.J. Massa, had [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
Luke Karg and his mentor Gary Foree fish together at Peaceful Valley Lake in Owensville in 2021 (Photo submitted).

The water on Truman Lake was colder and muddier than normal this April, making for some tough fishing conditions.

Luke Karg, of House Springs, had one last shot before graduating to win the Missouri TBF High School Trail Super Tournament for bass fishing ‚Äì which he and his then 16-year-old fishing partner, A.J. Massa, had won the year before.

It‚Äôs the last tournament of the season for the Missouri student program of The Bass Federation, and it‚Äôs also the final opportunity to earn enough points to be named Team of the Year ‚Äî the top-scoring duo in the state.

‚ÄúThe tournament itself meant a lot to us, with it being our last state tournament together,‚Äù Karg said. ‚ÄúIt was very tough. There was, at most, two inches of visibility in the water, but a lot of fishing is just adapting to the changes.‚Äù

Karg and Massa headed out on the water for two days for eight hours each. At the end of each day, they weighed their top five fish.

‚ÄúThe first day, they caught almost enough bass to win the tournament,‚Äù said Gary Foree, Karg‚Äôs mentor and family friend, who is a former professional fisherman. ‚ÄúThey had almost 19 pounds, which is insane. There hasn‚Äôt been a tournament in three years over 17 pounds on Truman Lake.‚Äù

They brought in 16 pounds on the second day, which would have brought their total up to nearly 35 pounds. But unfortunately it didn‚Äôt count. Their boat malfunctioned, making them miss the weigh in.

‚ÄúIt was pretty heart-wrenching,‚Äù Karg said. ‚ÄúIt was one of our best bags as a team on one of the most difficult days.‚Äù

Karg and Massa ended up taking second place at Truman Lake with one day‚Äôs worth of fish, and they still had enough points to be named Team of the Year, just as they were last year.

Karg has been part of the Team of the Year five years in a row, including as an incoming high-school freshman.

That title also sent the team to the TBF Student Angler Federation High School National Championship, which was held at Oklahoma‚Äôs Grand Lake O‚Äô the Cherokees in June.

Only the top two high-school teams from each state can compete, and Karg is the only person in Missouri to have qualified for that opportunity five years in a row, according to officials for the national championship.

‚ÄúTo be one of the top two teams in Missouri for five consecutive years is pretty freaking amazing,‚Äù said Karl Buck, who previously led the federation‚Äôs high school program in Missouri and was also Karg‚Äôs team leader. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just so proud it‚Äôs unbelievable. I mean, I can‚Äôt believe that I was involved in his upcoming as a fisherman.‚Äù

Karg began competitive fishing when he was 12 and participated in dozens of individual and team tournaments as a teen. Through it all, he struggled with an autoimmune illness that made him miss numerous days from school, he said, but he‚Äôs proud he still managed to graduate on time in May and continue fishing.

While it was grueling standing on a boat for hours under the hot sun, Karg said the national championship was exhilarating because some of the world‚Äôs top fishermen were watching.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the biggest tourn of the year, and a lot of people only get to go to it once, if even,‚Äù Karg said. ‚ÄúIt really could be the biggest tournament of your life.‚Äù

Karg has loved to fish ever since he could hold a rod, said his father Rick Karg. Even as early as 5, he said Karg could catch fish when the adults around him were coming up empty.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a magic,‚Äù Rick said. ‚ÄúMy scientific brain says, ‚ÄòIs there like a vibration from his heartbeat that travels down the line because he‚Äôs got his finger touching it, that the fish like?‚Äô‚Äù

Foree met Karg because of a life-changing promise he made to Karg‚Äôs mother, Becky Rumley.

Rumley was the nurse administering Foree‚Äôs chemotherapy treatment at St. Claire Hospital, and one day, she told him how much her nine-year-old son loved to fish. At the time, Foree thought he only had a few months to live.

‚ÄúI ended up telling her that if I survive this, I‚Äôll take him to Lake of the Ozarks and get him a five pounder because I used to be a [fishing] guide on the lake,‚Äù he said.

Foree did pull through, and when they went out fishing, Karg didn‚Äôt just catch one five-pound bass.

‚ÄúI caught three five-pound bass and two six pounders, and like a bunch of big fish,‚Äù Karg said. ‚ÄúIt is probably the best day of fishing in my life. And ever since then, he‚Äôs just dedicated a huge part of his life to help teach me and my partner.‚Äù

Foree was equally amazed after Karg pulled out nearly 40 pounds of fish that day.

‚ÄúHe just had the best day of fishing anybody could have,‚Äù Foree said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how I got him hooked on fishing.‚Äù

Over the years, Foree taught him about tracking fish through the different seasons and how to read the water and the banks. He also helped him get his first boat.

Now, Foree said, Karg‚Äôs instincts are his fishing superpower.

‚ÄúSo many times they won a tournament when the fishing was really tough, and Luke said, ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs try over here. That bank looks good,‚Äô‚Äù Foree said. ‚ÄúAnd they‚Äôll go over, and they‚Äôll catch enough fish on that bank to win the tournament.‚Äù

Karg believes his instincts have developed with the dozens of tournaments and countless hours of fishing.

‚ÄúOver time, it‚Äôs become more of an instinct, than having to think about, ‚ÄòOh, I should make a change,‚Äô‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt just naturally comes.‚Äù

For instance, at both the Truman Lake and national championship, Karg said he was painting his own custom lures while he was on the boat.

At Truman, he made the decision to color a half-inch chartreuse line on his spinner bait, he said, and he ended up catching much bigger fish, but less fish. If his lure had a straight tail, the catch was better as well, he said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all about how the bait works in the water,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe smallest little detail that can just trigger the fish to eat. That‚Äôs where a lot of the fun comes into it for me, is all the difficulties and fun little changes you can make. You can go from catching no fish for hours on end to catching your limit in a minute.‚Äù

Karl Buck remembers meeting Karg when he was about 12 on a dock at the Peaceful Valley Lake in Owensville, where Karg‚Äôs grandparents have a lake house. Buck used to run a student program called the Owensville Anglers, and they were finishing up a tournament that day.

‚ÄúWhen we were doing our weigh-in down at the dam, they came down to the boat ramp to inquire,‚Äù Buck said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôll probably hate this, but he was the most bashful young man, super quiet and reserved.‚Äù

The Owensville Anglers is how Karg got his start with tournament fishing, which Buck says is much different than regular fishing.

In a tournament, Buck said the first rule is ‚Äúfind five.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre fishing for five fish,‚Äù Buck said. ‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt matter what they weigh, they just got to be keepers,‚Äù meaning they are big enough to keep.

The fish go in the box where they‚Äôre kept alive and healthy, which is a standard conservation practice in the high-school tournaments.

‚ÄúAfter you have five, then you‚Äôre going to change your game,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs now no longer about just catching fish. You‚Äôre looking to upgrade the fish that you already have. Big fish get big for a reason. They‚Äôre hard to catch.‚Äù

Big fish know how to hide, and that‚Äôs where casting skills come into play, Foree said. He called Karg‚Äôs casting skills ‚Äúinsane.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe can skip jigs and lures and put them in places nobody else can,‚Äù Foree said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why he‚Äôs so good.‚Äù

But he wasn‚Äôt always that good, Buck remembers, which is why Karg earned the nickname ‚ÄúOops‚Äù after fishing with Buck and his son one day.

‚ÄúLuke throws this cast ‚Äî I believe it was a spinner bait ‚Äî and it winds up on the roof of this dock, stuck,‚Äù Buck said. ‚ÄúSo we go up and we get it. A little while later, he makes another cast and it gets stuck on somebody‚Äôs dock.‚Äù

After each time, Karg would just say, ‚ÄúOops‚Äù and the nickname was born. Buck said when they fished together this past summer, he was blown away at his talent.

Karg and Massa ended up placing 56th out of more than 200 teams in the national championship in Oklahoma.

‚ÄúWe lost three three-pounders that came off the boat,‚Äù Karg said after the tournament finished. ‚ÄúThat would have gotten us up to nine or 10 pounds. We would have been around 12th place probably.‚Äù

Karg said he‚Äôs proud of his accomplishment over this high school career, and he couldn‚Äôt have done it without his fishing partners Massa and previously Kyle Kannawurf, along with their boat captains.

‚ÄúNo one gives credit enough to our boat captains, which were both of our dads,‚Äù he said, ‚Äújust giving the time to drive all the way out there and standing with us out the boat for eight hours straight a day.‚Äù

As boat captain, Rick said he was in ‚Äúconstant amazement‚Äù at his son‚Äôs skill.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd just sit there and watch and think, ‚ÄòHow in the world are you doing this?‚Äô‚Äù Rick said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre like a super sharp shooter.‚Äù

Rick said he‚Äôs watched Karg fish for seven hours without catching anything, but he‚Äôd still have the focus and creativity change his strategy and get a big catch at the last minute. Karg‚Äôs humility and attitude are among the most impressive things about him, said Foree and Buck, particularly his ability to bounce back from setbacks.

‚ÄúHe never got rattled,‚Äù Foree said. ‚ÄúOh, he‚Äôd get upset if he lost a big fish, but he‚Äôd just say, ‚ÄòOkay, I learned something from that,‚Äô and go on to the next one. His ability to focus and stay focused in times of turmoil when he loses fish or the weather changes is very, very important in professional bass fishing.‚Äù

Karg¬†has his own boat detail business, and there are several career paths he‚Äôs interested in taking, including a professional fisherman.

‚ÄúBut for that, I would have to be away from home around 200 days of the year,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSo the one I‚Äôm probably gonna go with is a natural environmentalist studying fresh water fish.‚Äù

title: Thursday Bird Droppings: Merry Christmas, Birdland
description: The Orioles have already given their fans quite a few presents this offseason.
fullText:
Good morning, Camden Chatters, and Merry Christmas to all who celebrate.

For Orioles fans, it feels like Christmas has come early. For the first offseason in what feels like forever, the O‚Äôs have acted aggressively and decisively ‚Äî and spent a boatload of money ‚Äî to improve their team. Pete Alonso, of course, was the biggest gift of all, signing by far the largest free agent contract of the Mike Elias era. But the Orioles have doled out a bunch of other presents, too, from outfielder Taylor Ward to new closer Ryan Helsley to starting pitcher Shane Baz. They even brought back setup man Andrew Kittredge, who we‚Äôll call more of a stocking stuffer.

Don‚Äôt expect to find any other presents under the tree from the Orioles today. Christmas Day is usually a quiet one for MLB transactions. Baseball executives have families too, you know.

But once the holiday season is over, the O‚Äôs figure to be right back at work trying to fill the remaining holes on their roster. If they‚Äôre going to make a play for Japanese right-hander Tatsuya Imai, they‚Äôll need to do it soon; his posting period ends Jan. 2. If not Imai, maybe Elias will have another starting pitcher to gift to Orioles fans before winter is over.

‚ÄôTis the season to feel optimistic about the Orioles. Hopefully this feeling lasts through the spring and beyond.

If Orioles signed Valdez or Su√°rez, what would rotation look like? | MAILBAG ‚Äì BaltimoreBaseball.com

The answer: better. Much better.

The O‚Äôs need to get better against lefty pitching and their additions will help ‚Äì Steve Melewski

This is the second straight offseason the O‚Äôs have tried to address their problems against lefties. Let‚Äôs hope this year‚Äôs solutions turn out better than Tyler O‚ÄôNeill and Gary S√°nchez.

These 5 prospects improved their stock the most in 2025 ‚Äì MLB.com

MLB Pipeline‚Äôs Jim Callis has some encouraging words about O‚Äôs prospect Nate George (and some less-than-encouraging words about Enrique Bradfield Jr.).

Is today your birthday? Happy birthday! Four ex-Orioles were born on Christmas, including a 2025 Oriole, catcher Alex Jackson (30). Jackson was the sixth catcher the O‚Äôs used this year and turned out to be be one of the best, posting a .763 OPS and five homers in 36 games. The Orioles traded him to the Twins last month. Also born on this date were infielder Tom O‚ÄôMalley (65) and the late right-handers Charlie Beamon (b. 1934, d. 2016) and Mike Blyzka (b. 1928, d. 2004).

The Orioles have never made a roster move on Christmas Day, because of course they haven‚Äôt. Enjoy your day, everyone!

title: NBA Insider Unsure About Anfernee Simons‚Äô Playoff Fit With Celtics
description: Anfernee Simons‚Äô future with the Boston Celtics has been a subplot to the opening months of the 2025-26 NBA season. The score-first guard was acquired in the deal that sent Jrue Holiday to the Portland Trail Blazers during the summer. Simons is in the final year of his four-year $100 million deal. If the Celtics [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
Anfernee Simons‚Äô future with the Boston Celtics has been a subplot to the opening months of the 2025-26 NBA season. The score-first guard was acquired in the deal that sent Jrue Holiday to the Portland Trail Blazers during the summer. Simons is in the final year of his four-year $100 million deal.

If the Celtics choose to make a move close to the Feb. 5 trade deadline, the team views Simons as a logical trade chip. After all, it is better to flip him in return for long-term assets, rather than risk losing him for nothing in the summer.

However, if Simons does stay in Boston beyond the trade deadline, ESPN‚Äôs Tim Bontemps, speaking on a recent episode of ESPN‚Äôs ‚ÄòThe Hoop Collective‚Äô podcast, is not convinced he will have a significant role once the postseason begins.

‚ÄúFrankly, I don‚Äôt think Anfernee Simons is going to have a very big role in the playoffs either way,‚Äù Bontemps said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre going to be playing Derrick White and Payton Pritchard a ton of minutes. He‚Äôs (Simons) not at all a good defensive player. I think he‚Äôll be a liability in large part in the playoffs anyway.‚Äù

Simons has become an important part of Boston‚Äôs bench rotation. In 29 games this season, all from the bench, he‚Äôs averaging 13 points, 2.1 rebounds and 2.3 assists, shooting 43.1% from the field and 36.9% from deep. However, according to DunksandThrees, he‚Äôs still struggling on the defensive end, ranking in the bottom 10th percentile of guards for Defensive Estimated Plus/Minus.

Brad Stevens and the Celtics‚Äô front office will likely explore potential trades as the deadline approaches. It‚Äôs fair to assume that Simons will feature in those discussions, if for no other reason than to perform some due diligence on his potential market.

The problem Boston will face is that trading Simons will leave it short on depth at the guard position. As such, if Simons is moved, multiple additional moves could follow to ensure there‚Äôs enough balance within the roster ahead of the postseason.

NBA Analyst Weighs In on Jayson Tatum‚Äôs Potential Return

title: 3 Things to watch for in Cavs at Knicks
description: The Cavs are in New York for Christmas.
fullText:
Merry Christmas and Happy Holidays. The Cleveland Cavaliers are in the Mecca for a matchup with the New York Knicks.

The Cavs and Knicks have a history of bad blood between them. Their meeting in the 2023 NBA Playoffs was a stepping stone for New York and a reality check for the Cavaliers. The Cavs have been carrying that loss with them ever since ‚Äî and they are hungry for a chance to redeem themselves in a potential rematch.

Both Cleveland and New York entered the season as favorites to win the Eastern Conference. That might have changed recently as the Detroit Pistons wedge themselves into the mix and the Cavaliers struggle to get out of the gates. But make no mistake, these two rosters are still among the most talented in the East. This game could carry weight by the time the playoffs begin.

Comment on articles, community posts

New, improved notifications system!

The Knicks had a slow start last season as growing pains muddied their process. But following a trip to the Western Conference Finals, a coaching change and some roster tweaks, they‚Äôve gotten off to a much better start this season.

New York holds the 2nd-best record in the East. They have the 2nd best offense, 14th best defense and 5th best net rating this season according to Cleaning the Glass.

This is a team that has found its identity and plays basketball like they trust each other. They can give as good a challenge as any.

It‚Äôs pretty simple. The Cavs have had a rough December full of low points. But after winning back-to-back games at the start of the week, they have a chance to really make things right with a statement win over their rival on Christmas Day.

title: How to watch Lions at Vikings on Christmas: TV, time, online streaming
description: All the TV, streaming, radio, announcer information you need for Detroit Lions vs. Minnesota Vikings on Christmas.
fullText:
The Detroit Lions and Minnesota Vikings face off on Christmas afternoon‚Äîthe middle game of an NFL tripleheader. While the stakes may not be as high as the Lions or Vikings want, it is still an opportunity to take part in one of our biggest passions, and surrounded by loved ones, no less.

This game is being broadcast on Netflix, the popular streaming platform, but there are plenty of other ways to watch Lions vs. Vikings on Christmas. Here‚Äôs all the information you‚Äôll need to watch.

The game is on Thursday, December 25, at 4:30 p.m. ET

The game is being played at U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis, Minnesota.

The game is being streamed over Netflix worldwide. However, if you don‚Äôt have Netflix, there are some other options. For one, if you‚Äôre in the local Metro Detroit area, the game will be broadcast on CBS. If you‚Äôre not in the local area, you can also stream the game on a mobile device if you have an NFL+ subscription.

Yes! It‚Äôs available worldwide on Netflix.

There are three streaming options:

Netflix (available to everyone)

CBS News app (for local fans only)

The Netflix broadcasting crew is: Noah Eagle, Drew Brees, AJ Ross, Dianna Russini.

As always, you can get your fix of Dan Miller and Lomas Brown over on 97.1 The Ticket or whatever Lions Radio Network affiliate is available in your area.

It‚Äôs also available on national radio on Westwood One. The announcers for that crew are Jason Benetti and Ryan Harris.

Or, if you want all of that information condensed:

When: Thursday, December 25, 2025 ‚Äî 4:30 p.m. ET
Where: U.S. Bank Stadium ‚Äî Minneapolis, MN 
TV: Netflix
Local TV: CBS
Announcers: Noah Eagle, Drew Brees, AJ Ross, Dianna Russini
Online streaming: Netflix, NFL+, or CBS News (local only) 
Local Radio: 97.1 The Ticket (Local affiliates here)
Local radio announcers: Dan Miller, Lomas Brown, T.J. Lang
National radio: Westwood One
National radio announcers: Jason Benetti, Ryan Harris

title: 'A million choices': Lakers' defense will get a Christmas Day test vs. Rockets
description: Coach JJ Redick says the Lakers will not make all the correct choices, but "can you make the vast majority of 'em correctly? It gives you a chance to win."
fullText:
It‚Äôs not the lineups, the injuries or necessarily the system. The cause of the Lakers' defensive demise is a thousand little decisions gone wrong.

‚ÄúIt comes down to just making the choice,‚Äù coach JJ Redick said after the Lakers gave up 132 points in a blowout loss to the Phoenix Suns on Tuesday. ‚ÄúIt's making the choice. There's shortcuts you can take or you can do the hard thing and you can make the second effort or you can sprint back or you can't. It's just a choice and there's a million choices in a game, and you're very likely not gonna make every choice correctly. But can you make the vast majority of 'em correctly? It gives you a chance to win.‚Äù

Coming off back-to-back losses for the first time this season, the Lakers (19-9) are ranked 28th in defensive rating in the last 14 games entering a Christmas Day showcase against the Houston Rockets at 5 p.m. PST at Crypto.com Arena.

The Lakers, without any individual shutdown defenders, need a perfectly executed team defense to compete. But 15 different starting lineups in 28 games has delayed some of the team's ability to build continuity. The Lakers have had their full complement of 14 standard contract players for two games.

Forward Rui Hachimura (groin) and Luka Doncic (leg) could return Thursday. Guard Gabe Vincent, one of the team‚Äôs top defensive options on the perimeter, will miss his fourth game with lower-back soreness. Center Jaxson Hayes tweaked his left ankle in the second quarter of Tuesday‚Äôs loss and didn‚Äôt return.

The Rockets (17-10) limp into the Christmas Day blockbuster with their own struggles. The team thought to be one of the few who could challenge Oklahoma City in the West has lost five of its last seven games. Three of the losses were in overtime and four came against teams currently out of the play-in picture, including Tuesday‚Äôs loss to the Clippers.

Led by Kevin Durant‚Äôs 25.2 points, the Rockets are a statistical anomaly in the sped up, possession-maximizing modern NBA. They have the third-ranked offense in the league despite being one of the slowest. They shoot the fewest three-pointers per game, but make them at a 40% clip that ranks second, and dominate the glass with NBA-leading 48.7 rebounds and 16.1 offensive rebounds per game.

Houston‚Äôs physicality and expertise on the boards could be especially worrisome for a team that still has to consciously choose defense on a possession-by-possession basis instead of consistently living up to a standard of playing hard.

‚ÄúThere's really no defense, no scheme we can do when we're giving up offensive rebounds in crucial moments like we are, our [opponents] are getting wherever they want on the court,‚Äù guard Marcus Smart said after Tuesday‚Äôs loss. ‚ÄúAnd there's no help, there's no resistance, there's no urgency. ‚Ä¶ It's on us.‚Äù

The Suns grabbed 12 offensive rebounds against the Lakers on 35 missed shots, an offensive rebounding rate of 34.3%. After the Suns scored a three-pointer by twice grabbing offensive rebounds off tipped balls, Lakers players had an animated discussion in a timeout with Smart was gesturing toward center Deandre Ayton about tipping rebounds. Ayton, who finished with 10 rebounds and 12 points, and Smart ended the timeout with a high-five.

‚Äú[I need to] just continue to talk to guys, even though sometimes they might not want to hear it,‚Äù said Smart, a free-agent addition the Lakers coveted for his leadership and tenacity on defense. ‚ÄúEspecially when we losing, nobody wants to hear it, myself included, but also understand that it's integral for us to hear those things, to see and to be able to talk to one another and figure it out as players on the court, because we're the ones out there.‚Äù

Redick intentionally built in moments for players to connect and communicate during every timeout this season before coaches speak. The strategy was meant to encourage players to take a larger leadership role. ‚ÄúChampionship communication‚Äù was one of the team‚Äôs three pillars.

Along with ‚Äúchampionship shape,‚Äù Redick also asked his team to build ‚Äúchampionship habits.‚Äù Living up to the mantras is easier said than done.

‚ÄúIt's not the easy choice,‚Äù Redick said. ‚ÄúIt's human nature. ‚Ä¶ We do it on a daily basis. We make easy choices cause it's comfortable. Comfortable doesn't win.‚Äù

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.

title: Cowboys news: Dallas moves Tyler Guyton to injured reserve
description: Here's the latest news surrounding the Dallas Cowboys.
fullText:
Second-year left tackle Tyler Guyton is done for the 2025 season.

The¬†Cowboys¬†could get one of their Pro Bowlers back in the lineup on Christmas.

Defensive tackle Quinnen Williams¬†(neck) was one of four Cowboys listed as questionable on the team‚Äôs injury report for Thursday‚Äôs game against the Washington Commanders.

Guard Tyler Booker (ankle), corner Caelen Carson (hamstring) and wide receiver Ryan Flournoy (knee) were also listed as questionable.

Five Cowboys were ruled out for Thursday: Payton Turner (ribs), DeMarvion Overshown (concussion), Phil Mafah (shoulder), Josh Butler (knee) and Tyler Guyton (ankle),¬†who was placed on injured reserve Thursday.

Things are a little different this year under Brian Schottenheimer.

Another year, another lost season. The Dallas Cowboys have two games left to play and once again¬†find themselves mathematically eliminated from the playoff picture. Despite undergoing major changes to the coaching staff over the previous offseason, the Cowboys are on the same trajectory as they were last year under Mike McCarthy.

The situation in Year 1 of Brian Schottenheimer has caused many to call for something along the lines of an ‚Äúorganic tank.‚Äù By replacing proven veterans with young up-and-comers the Cowboys can simultaneously learn more about their roster and increase their odds of losing in a somewhat respectable fashion. ¬†Obviously, the motivation behind that would be to¬†gain better draft position in the 2026 NFL draft.

It was a similar plea heard around Cowboys Nation in McCarthy‚Äôs final season last year. The year was 2024 and McCarthy had just finished his fifth and final season under contract. After three consecutive 12-win seasons, 2024 marked a clear decrescendo for McCarthy‚Äôs tenure.

While the plea and circumstances behind it are similar for this year, the situations are apples and oranges. The first season in any head coach‚Äôs term is about building a culture. Messages are important and have lasting consequences. Send the wrong message early and a coach may never be able to overcome. It‚Äôs why letting off the gas, even a little, is a dangerous proposition, even when there‚Äôs seemingly nothing to gain.

What the Cowboys need to do to get their seventh win of the season.

In a year that‚Äôs been effective all across the board for the Cowboys offense, one area they‚Äôve executed at a high level in is the short passing game, with attempts that are between the line of scrimmage and 10 yards down field.

For the year, the Cowboys have the third most passing yards in the short passing game (1,716) with 12 touchdowns and five interceptions to go alongside it.

In their first meeting with the Commanders earlier this season, Dak Prescott completed 15 of his 20 passing attempts within 10 yards for 81 yards and two touchdowns.

Dallas has multiple different ways that they can get to those types of plays. George Pickens‚Äô quick slant routes were one of them. We‚Äôve seen quick throws from Prescott to his tight ends on curls routes too. Or, Prescott can get into his groove in the play action game and hit someone on a crosser as well.

Ultimately, the Cowboys will have their choice for how they can use the short passing game to move downfield. The good news is, the Commanders have struggled recently to get pressure on the quarterback since their first meeting with Dallas, when they lost DE and former Cowboy Dorance Armstrong for the season to a knee injury. Since Armstrong‚Äôs injury, Washington has gone from a 40.7% pressure rate (third-highest in the NFL) to 25.9% (second-lowest).

Chance to try new things on defense

We saw a little bit of experimentation from the Cowboys in a few ways last week, most notably with defensive coordinator Matt Eberflus moving from the sideline to the coaches booth in order to try and gain a better perspective of the defense.

Another moment that stood out was a specific formation where the Cowboys had three down linemen, and Donovan Ezeiruaku lined up like a linebacker and rushed against the interior of the offensive line as opposed to the outside like he usually does. He was trying to spring open Kenny Clark on a stunt, but the Cowboys couldn‚Äôt get home.

While that specific instance didn‚Äôt work, this week‚Äôs game and next week‚Äôs serve as an opportunity to continue to try different things and see if there‚Äôs anything that you can find success with that could carry over into next season.

For example, and I‚Äôm not saying this is the sole option that could be experimented with nor am I hinting it‚Äôll happen, what about trying some more six-man blitzes? The Cowboys have sent six rushes 5.8% of the time this year, the tenth-lowest mark in the league. Could that be a way where they can finally turn pressure into sacks?

Believe it or not, the Cowboys have recorded the 15th¬†highest pressure rate in the NFL this season at 34.7%. Pressure is well and good, but getting the quarterback to the ground and forcing them into bad decisions is what makes that number look better. The Cowboys have struggled to do the latter half of that equation, but could try some new things against Washington considering the quarterback situation they are in.

Matt Eberflus has plenty of pressure on him in Week 17.

The¬†Dallas Cowboys¬†are intent on playing their starters on Christmas Day despite being eliminated from playoff contention,¬†including quarterback Dak Prescott.

The¬†Washington Commanders¬†don‚Äôt really have a choice. Not only is starting QB Jayden Daniels done for the year, but now it won‚Äôt even be QB2 Marcus Mariota taking the field on Thursday.

Josh Johnson to face Cowboys defense

Long-time NFL journeyman Josh Johnson will start at quarterback for the Commanders, Washington head coach and former Cowboys defensive coordinator Dan Quinn announced on Wednesday.

Mariota is dealing with a hand injury and he entered the concussion protocol in the third quarter of the Commanders‚Äô loss to the¬†Philadelphia Eagles¬†last weekend. Johnson recorded a 28.7 passer rating in his relief, completing five of nine pass attempts for 43 yards and an interception.

Johnson is better known for having played for 14 NFL teams, the most in league history. The last time he recorded a start was in 2021 for the¬†Baltimore Ravens, when he completed 70% of his passes for 304 yards, two touchdowns, and a pick in a 41-21 loss to the¬†Cincinnati Bengals.

Matt Eberflus can‚Äôt afford a bad game

Talk about a nothing to gain, everything to lose scenario for defensive coordinator Matt Eberflus.

The front office‚Äôs comments have already made it clear that¬†Eberflus is on the hot seat. Prior to Week 16, Jones said the team‚Äôs final three-game stretch would be big criterion when deciding on the defensive coordinator‚Äôs fate. So far, it‚Äôs not going great after J.J. McCarthy put on a career performance against Dallas last weekend.

And here‚Äôs the thing: I don‚Äôt see how a good game against Johnson would raise his stock. The guy is about to start his tenth career game since first arriving in the league in 2009. But a bad outing? It could drive Eberflus‚Äô stock into the ground.

Cowboys owner and GM Jerry Jones recently pointed out how struggling quarterbacks have consistently outperformed expectations when facing the defense. It can‚Äôt happen on Thursday, right?

title: Northwestern safety Robert Fitzgerald, shaped by dad‚Äôs memory, worked his way from scout team to All-Big Ten
description: Northwestern assistant head coach Harlon Barnett has a long list of nicknames ready to use whenever he addresses or talks about safety Robert Fitzgerald. The Terminator. The World‚Äôs Greatest Tackler. The Face of the Big Ten. The Eraser.
fullText:
Northwestern assistant head coach Harlon Barnett has a long list of nicknames ready to use whenever he addresses or talks about safety Robert Fitzgerald.

The Terminator. The World‚Äôs Greatest Tackler. The Face of the Big Ten. The Eraser. The General. The Example. Mr. Consistent.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs going to start forgetting his own name,‚Äù Barnett said.

Fitzgerald has given Barnett a lot of reason to talk about him in a breakout season that continues at noon Friday in Northwestern‚Äôs game against Central Michigan in the GameAbove Sports Bowl on ESPN.

The redshirt junior goes into the game at Detroit‚Äôs Ford Field as the Big Ten leader with 68 solo tackles for a Wildcats defense that fueled their 6-6 regular season. He ranked fourth in the conference with 109 tackles and also had 6¬Ω tackles for a loss, three passes defended, an interception and a fumble recovery.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs maximizing his gifts, talents and abilities that the Lord has given him,‚Äù Barnett said. ‚ÄúAnd he takes no days off.‚Äù

Fitzgerald‚Äôs season, for which he was named second-team All-Big Ten by coaches, comes after three years of working his way into bigger roles with Northwestern. He began with the Wildcats scout team and then played primarily on special teams in his first two seasons before earning more time on defense last year.

Throughout the climb, he focused on the process, determined that when the Wildcats needed him, he would be prepared.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got to put the work in, day in, day out, no matter how long it takes,‚Äù Fitzgerald said. ‚ÄúBut eventually your opportunity is going to come. And when that opportunity came, I knew that I was going to be ready based on all the work that I‚Äôve been putting in for the past three years, on and off the field, in the weight room, in the training room, getting my body right, learning the playbook, studying film.‚Äù

Fitzgerald‚Äôs approach ‚Äî and his understanding of the value of each day ‚Äî was developed in part before his time at Northwestern. During his senior year of high school in Dallas, he watched his father, Matthew, fight ALS, and his memories of his dad have shaped how he lives now.

The Fitzgerald family would have Italian beef and Lou Malnati‚Äôs shipped to Dallas for Chicago Bears-Green Bay Packers games. Fitzgerald and his sister, Olivia, were Packers fans because of their mom, Amy, who is from Wisconsin. Matt, who grew up in the Wildwood/Edgebrook area of Chicago, cheered for the Bears.

‚ÄúHe always said that my mom brainwashed me and my sister to be Packers fans,‚Äù Fitzgerald said.

Fitzgerald said his father was passionate about the work he did as a marketing executive. Midway through his career, he met Mark Cuban at the gym, became friends with him and became the Mavericks senior vice president for marketing and communications, a job that allowed Fitzgerald to be a Mavs ball boy and meet Dirk Nowitzki as a kid.

Matt could light up a room and was passionate about his family and friends, a trait Fitzgerald carries with him to his relationships.

And the former Loyola Academy safety loved football, a passion he passed on to his son. Fitzgerald remembers spending countless hours on the couch watching NFL Sunday Ticket with his dad. They would play in the backyard, reenacting Super Bowl-winning drives, making sideline grabs or playing goal-line tackle, the latter game one his mother didn‚Äôt love.

Fitzgerald said his dad was the biggest influence on his football career, giving him everything he needed to be successful. And he kept cheering on his son even after he was diagnosed with ALS the summer before Fitzgerald‚Äôs senior year at Jesuit College Prep. Fitzgerald, an All-State safety and running back that season, would look up into the stands to see his dad.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd be like, ‚ÄòWhatever I‚Äôm going through ‚Äî I‚Äôm tired out here; I‚Äôm exhausted ‚Äî whatever I‚Äôm going through is minuscule compared to what he‚Äôs going through,‚Äô‚Äù Fitzgerald said. ‚ÄúSo that kind of drove me in high school my senior year, and I‚Äôve kind of been able to use that as fuel going forward.‚Äù

Fitzgerald, who is no relation to former Wildcats coach Pat Fitzgerald, chose Northwestern in part because of his father‚Äôs connection to the Chicago area. His grandmother still lived at the time in the same home Matt grew up in. Fitzgerald‚Äôs aunt lives in Naperville. His dad‚Äôs friends are around and come to games.

Illinois and Northwestern are headed to bowl games: Here‚Äôs what to know

But Matt didn‚Äôt get to see him play for the Wildcats. Matt died on July 22, 2022, just as Fitzgerald was beginning fall camp with Northwestern.

‚ÄúThe whole thing changed my perspective on life for sure,‚Äù Fitzgerald said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt take a single day for granted anymore. Just watching the way he handled it and the way he attacked it just really was amazing to see. And it was amazing to see how strong my mom was throughout the entire disease. And it was also amazing how many people showed up for my family. The community really showed up for us.‚Äù

When Fitzgerald thinks about how he got through that time in his life ‚Äî getting acclimated at a new school in the midst of losing his father ‚Äî he said his family helped, especially his mom, who was ‚Äúthe rock throughout the whole thing.‚Äù

And his Northwestern teammates and coaches helped too. It wasn‚Äôt just letting him know they were sorry or there for him. Sometimes it was just acting normally, because he needed that too.

‚ÄúMy teammates just really rallied around me, and they kind of became like 110 brothers that I never had,‚Äù he said.

Fitzgerald‚Äôs freshman season wasn‚Äôt easy on the field either as he realized he would be playing behind guys with several years of experience.

He played scout team for a 1-11 squad before getting a few reps on special teams at the end of the year, which became a redshirt season. But he believed that if he kept working, he could increase his opportunities.

In his second season, he started on three special teams units and played in a third-down subpackage. By his third year, he made the defensive rotation and started some at nickel for the Wildcats.

Barnett, who joined Braun‚Äôs staff before the 2024 season, saw a player who was intentional and diligent with his work. He told Fitzgerald at the end of that season that he probably should have played more at safety, and he saw that message take hold to build Fitzgerald‚Äôs confidence in the offseason.

‚ÄúI saw toughness,‚Äù Barnett said. ‚ÄúI saw a willingness to get better. I saw a guy that takes coaching. He‚Äôs one of those guys who‚Äôs going to do exactly what you tell him. He‚Äôs going to take it to heart, he‚Äôs going to listen to you and he‚Äôs going to apply it. And that‚Äôs what you like to see as a coach.‚Äù

Barnett, who played defensive back at Michigan State and in the NFL, always tells his players that they need to believe that they are the best player on the field.

Recapping an eventful 2025 for Chicago sports on ‚Äî and off ‚Äî the field

Fitzgerald said he knew he was meant to be in the starting-safety role after the opener against Tulane, when he had 13 tackles. But his confidence was really in place by the fourth game of the season against UCLA, a 17-14 Northwestern win in which Fitzgerald had nine tackles, including a tackle for a loss. He wouldn‚Äôt freak out if he missed a tackle. He told himself he was the best player on the field.

‚ÄúThen he started playing like that ‚Äî ‚ÄòI‚Äôm the baddest dude out here. I‚Äôm the baddest guy on the field,‚Äô‚Äù Barnett said.

Fitzgerald had numerous big plays in Northwestern‚Äôs near-upset of Michigan at Wrigley Field on Nov. 15. He had a career-high 15 tackles, including a tackle for a loss, and picked off quarterback Bryce Underwood in the fourth quarter, but Barnett got excited about a hit on a Wolverines running back late in the fourth.

‚ÄúHe came in and smacked one of the running backs,‚Äù Barnett said. ‚ÄúI am vicariously playing through the players. And so, oh, man, I was so fired up. ‚Ä¶ And I don‚Äôt like Michigan, so that also adds to it.‚Äù

Recapping an eventful 2025 for Chicago sports on ‚Äî and off ‚Äî the field

Chicago basketball report: WNBA players authorize a strike ‚Äî and ‚ÄòAin‚Äôt no Christmas‚Äô for Notre Dame men

Keaton Wagler powers No. 20 Illinois past Missouri 91-48 for the biggest blowout in Braggin‚Äô Rights rivalry

Notre Dame ‚Äî with 96-game rivalry series vs. USC now on pause ‚Äî announces home-and-home with BYU

Hannah Hildago posts triple-double in No. 20 Notre Dame women‚Äôs 110-38 win over Bellarmine

Fitzgerald will have one more chance this season to show up Friday against Central Michigan. He said the Wildcats want to finish with a winning record, send their seniors out on a high note and build some momentum heading into next season.

Barnett said in the offseason Fitzgerald will continue to work on his speed and change of direction, on honing his already solid ball skills and tackling and improving his ‚Äúvision and break‚Äù to where the quarterback is sending the ball.

He expects him to continue to develop his leadership too. Fitzgerald delivered a speech to the team before the Tulane game to rally his teammates and said he is working on being a more vocal leader, which comes naturally after he feels like he has earned it.

That merit has come this season. Earlier this year, Northwestern coach David Braun said Fitzgerald should be proud of the demeanor and the consistency with which he has played, adding ‚Äúthere‚Äôs no one in this program that reflects our values more than that young man.‚Äù

Fitzgerald has thought about how his dad would view this breakout season, and he knows he would revel in it.

‚ÄúHe would eat this season up,‚Äù Fitzgerald said. ‚ÄúHe would love to see me. I know he‚Äôs watching, but he would love to be in those stands and see me out there, just like I was playing in high school.‚Äù

title: New York Jets News: For Qwan‚Äôtez Stiggers ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs Just Been Falling Into Place‚Äô

title: 2025-26 World Junior Championships PRIMER: Everything you need to know!
description: It‚Äôs the premiere teenager tournament, this time located in Minnesota!
fullText:
What is it?: Teenager hockey at the highest level being played in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada!

When is it?: The games start December 26th, and the medal round begins just after New Year‚Äôs Day on the 2nd.

Where can I watch it?: TSN in Canada, NHLN in the states, apparently TUBI will also have it if you stream your hockey.

Who‚Äôs the defending champs?: The United States, who is going for a threepeat this year!

Why should I care?: Why, you get to see the NHL stars of tomorrow face off for World Juniors glory! Gavin McKenna gets to wow you before he even gets the chance to play for an NHL team! Also it‚Äôs pretty inoffensive hockey that people get super wound up over while you‚Äôre puttering around the house during the holidays, so there aught to be some good yucks at certain fanbases (read: Canada‚Äôs) expense. Also, the relegation round is always a fun treat for those who want to see imperfect, desperate hockey, a personal favorite of mine.

Team USA: James Hagens, Will Zellers

One must imagine Sweden happy, because once again they should be set up to be a powerhouse‚Ä¶and it might shock you to learn that nobody is concerned because they have to get past the US and then will have to beat Canada or Finland in order to get the Gold Medal they so desperately crave. There‚Äôs just no winning for them unless they win it all, and that will be tough. In the round robin they usually do pretty well, and their roster this year is once again damn good; Sascha Boumedienne, Loke Krantz, Ivar Stenburg, Anton Frondell, with decent netminders in Goos and H√§renstam suggests they will be just as good as they usually are. Problem is, we know that. We know they will likely cruise to another Group top or close to it. Then they have to play in the elimination round. Tre Kronor‚Äôs biggest issue remains that elimination round play, and who knows if this version of Sweden can survive it. I‚Äôm pretty sure they can‚Ä¶they just have to, you know‚Ä¶do it.

Slovakia remains interested in proving they are A) Not Mad about Juraj Slafkovsky‚Äôs comments that suggest the federation is indolent, and B) You can ignore their considerable interest in buddying up to the Russian Federation because they‚Äôre A-Okay, baby. Slovakia unfortunately does have some issues facing them coming into the tourney: their 2023 class has aged out entirely, and a vast majority of their team is so, so young. In some cases that may benefit them, as there‚Äôs less tape on these kids and the ones who they do have tape on are pretty good. For most however‚Ä¶well, they don‚Äôt have the same caliber of player they used to in a division where Sweden and the US are, and they usually had a good chance to beat the US up ‚Äòtill now. They‚Äôre going to have to hope Michal Pradel can hold the fort long enough for guys like Michal Capos, Jan Chovan, and Michal Svrcek can get these youngsters moving like they can. I don‚Äôt think they‚Äôre necessarily worse than the rest of their division, but I certainly wouldn‚Äôt put them any higher than 3rd unless Pradel starts doing 3rd eye goaltending.

Here‚Äôs the thing: by all accounts, Germany should be in trouble. Their defense is kind of awkward and not especially noteworthy, and they‚Äôre banking on a WHL goalie to be their rock in net. That is a rock I think they could trust in spurts here or there, but maybe not all the way. Why I think they escape relegation this year is that Die Eismannschaft is more offensively gifted than Switzerland; especially up front. Max Penkin, Max Schafer, and David Lewandowski have all found great success this year in Canadian Junior/DEL play, and zee Germans might have something in brothers Timo and Fabio Kose, who play different positions but have shown great flashes of talent against grown-ass men in the DEL. Against players their own age? They may yet shine. Veillard, while I don‚Äôt necessarily trust an .890 SV% goalie, is a vet for this squad, and I imagine they will rally around him.

It breaks my heart to suggest Switzerland may end up on the relegation block this year, I have loved their fundamentals only, no funny business kind of hockey for years, but ultimately the level of talent at the WJC is improving, and so far the Swiss have failed to meet the moment. It stinks especially because they do have interesting talent! They have

After Canada publicly embarrassed themselves last year and the year before, The True North appear to have taken a much more humble approach to the World Juniors of casually bringing everyone who is good and available to the World Juniors. Even better, the omissions this year were largely because the Pacific teams that they were signed to still want them to be on the roster, and thus can‚Äôt justify assigning them. Even better than that, Group B is about as easy a division as you could ask for if Canada really is as built up as they say they are‚Ä¶which is what I would say, had Gavin McKenna not made it clear that he‚Äôs prone to error as much as anyone else, and Sweden doesn‚Äôt even have to play Canada until a hypothetical medal round. In general, a lot rides on Canada right now. They‚Äôve been slipping badly over the past few tourneys and have turned ‚Äúunderdog gets first win over Canada‚Äù into an almost yearly spectacle. Regardless of how you feel about their place in the sport, Canada in the tourneys that count does not have the luxury of expecting to be good anymore. In short, they need to run away with this one and quickly, or we are once again going to start a dialogue about the decision-making corps for the Red and White (and sometimes black).

Finland‚Äôs effort in the early parts of this tournament have always been a bit slow; especially with their proclivity for penalties, so don‚Äôt be surprised if they look like they‚Äôre in trouble to start out. What they are however, is in a very weird place. They‚Äôre without Konsta Helenius; their current premiere prospect of World Juniors age, and as such are going to need to adjust to life without him. They‚Äôre not screwed by a long shot, but now they need to focus down on other talents to help them out. In net, as per usual, they will have a murderer‚Äôs row of good goalies to choose from; Kim Saarinen and Petteri Rimpinen will once again be their rock in net, allowing talents like Julius Miettinen, Emil Hemming, Matias Vanhanen, and Max Westergard to do what they usually do best; cause a ruckus on the boards, rip off a solid pass, and score goals. Losing Helenius however means they lose a level of dynamism that would have otherwise given them an edge against the Group leader once we get to that point on the calendar. Still, the Finns always find a way to drag teams down to their level, so while Canada might get the edge on them to start, they always find a way to crawl back in and make you regret it. Also, Rimpinen has the coolest pads in this tournament. Bar none.

Czechia has traditionally been an offense or bust kind of team; one that‚Äôs free-wheeling and fun if a little chaotic. That chaos allowed them to be Bronze Medalists at last year‚Äôs tourney. Is that gonna change? Maybe! Granted, they still have plenty of impressive and fun forwards they can call on to make their brand of frantic and fun hockey work, but now they‚Äôll have an extra hand from the backend; they‚Äôve decided to bring Radim Mrtka, Jakub Fibigr, Vashek Blanar, and Adam Jiricek to the dance, and from the skaters alone it seems like Czechia plans to survive this tourney through blistering offense.

Latvia has the benefit of their upset win over Canada to allow them to survive through this tournament. That‚Äôs probably what‚Äôs going to get them through this tournament entirely because otherwise Latvia has lost a lot of the talent that made them so special last year. They will have to rely on the work of players who‚Äôve spent a lot of time abroad: Roberts Naudins has been tearing it up for Shattuck St. Marys Prep, Daniels Serkins has been doing great for SC Bern in Switzerland, and of course; the Latvians have their wunderkind; Alberts Smits, who is projected to be a first round pick this year. They do have a team attitude and game plan that usually makes them a lot tougher to play than you might expect, but they also tend to need their goalies to be lights out. Of the three they brought; Nils Roberts Maurins would likely have to play way above his paygrade to keep them in games. Otherwise, their tournament will be as per usual; passionate fans, painful results.

There are going to be players on Denmark with more middle names than goals this year. Have fun playing Switzerland in the knockout round!

It looks like this! The games begin on December 26th, and the Elimination round begins on January 2nd.

title: 2025 NFL Week 17: Hart‚Äôs Picks
description: Mile High Report‚Äôs Christopher Hart gives his picks for Week 17 of the 2025 NFL regular season.
fullText:
Week 17 of the NFL regular season is upon us. Only two more weeks of regular season picks are left. My Week 16 picks were not optimal. I picked just 9 of 16 games correctly. Through fifteen weeks I‚Äôm now sitting at 160-80 with predictions. Let‚Äôs see if I can do better than I did last week.

Christmas Day (Early Game) ‚ÄîDallas Cowboys at Washington Commanders

Had events played out differently in the regular season, this game could have been garnered huge playoff implications. Unfortunately, these NFC East rivals are both eliminated from playoff contention. I think the Cowboys end up winning this one on the road.

Christmas Day (Afternoon Game) ‚Äî Detroit Lions at Minnesota Vikings

The only way the Lions can make the playoffs is by winning out and the Packers losing their final two games. It‚Äôs a longshot, but stranger things have happened. Not that he has been great, but J.J. McCarthy won‚Äôt be playing in this one. That being said, I think Detroit will win this one easily.

Christmas Day (Night Game) ‚Äî Denver Broncos at Kansas City Chiefs

The Broncos lost to the Jacksonville Jaguars last Sunday. Denver still controls their own destiny and can earn the AFC‚Äôs top seed if they beat the Chiefs and Chargers the next two weeks. They‚Äôve got a lot of mistakes to clean up, but I have a feeling they will deliver Broncos Country a present on Christmas night and beat Kansas City.

Saturday Football (Afternoon Game) ‚Äî Houston Texans at Los Angeles Chargers

Both the Texans and Chargers are poised to make the postseason. The only question is will it be as a wildcard team or division champion. The stakes are huge for both of them. Houston‚Äôs defense has been the strength of their team and Justin Herbert has impressed despite numerous key losses to their offensive line. All things considered, I think DeMeco Ryans has his team ready to win this one.

DeMeco Ryans on the game vs the Chargers:

‚ÄúNo doubt about it. It‚Äôs defintley a playoff game. It was a playoff game for us last week. That‚Äôs where you want to be in December, playing meaningful games & that‚Äôs what this team has earned.‚Äù pic.twitter.com/sRbAg9pofV

‚Äî Houston Stressans (@TexansCommenter) December 23, 2025

Saturday Football (Evening Game) ‚Äî Baltimore Ravens at Green Bay Packers

The Ravens aren‚Äôt out of the playoffs yet, but their chances of making the postseason are slim. Currently, the Packers are the NFC‚Äôs seventh seed and can punch their playoff ticket with a win. With a back contusion suffered in Week 16, there is a good chance Lamar Jackson doesn‚Äôt play. If so, that should make the Packers heavy favorites in this one. I‚Äôm taking Green Bay at home.

Sunday Football (Early Game) ‚Äî Arizona Cardinals at Cincinnati Bengals

This Sunday game is an uninteresting matchup with two teams out of playoff contention. After laying a goose egg a few weeks ago, the Bengals kicked things into high gear last weekend and scored a lot of points. I think they will do the same on Sunday, as the Cardinals are in a tailspin having lost seven games in a row. I‚Äôm picking Cincinnati.

Sunday Football (Early Game) ‚Äî Pittsburgh Steelers at Cleveland Browns

The formula is simple for the Steelers to make the postseason. A win over the Browns guarantees them the AFC North title and the opportunity to host a Wild Card round playoff game. Could the Browns play spoiler? Sure, but don‚Äôt count on that. I‚Äôm confident that Pittsburgh takes care of business here.

Sunday Football (Early Game) ‚Äî New Orleans Saints at Tennessee Titans

The Saints have won three in a row and are now 5-10 on the season. Meanwhile, the Titans are a 3-12 team coming off a victory against the Chiefs in Week 16. There isn‚Äôt anything compelling about this matchup to really write about. That being said, I‚Äôll take New Orleans on the road.

THREE IN A ROW DUBS#Saints | @Gatorade pic.twitter.com/br2Fm49xjA

‚Äî New Orleans Saints (@Saints) December 21, 2025

Sunday Football (Early Game) ‚Äî Jacksonville Jaguars at Indianapolis Colts

The Jaguars earned a playoff berth defeating the Broncos last weekend. They have a path to the AFC‚Äôs top seed, though it will take some help. In order for that to happen, beating the Colts who have dropped five games in a row is a must. Based on what I saw against Denver last Sunday, I like their chances against Indianapolis.

Sunday Football (Early Game) ‚Äî Tampa Bay Buccaneers at Miami Dolphins

The Buccaneers started off the season hot but have dropped three games in a row. They have to win this game, and the Panthers need to lose against the Seahawks in order to keep their postseason hopes alive. I‚Äôm expecting both of those things to happen, with the Week 18 Buccaneers/Panthers matchup deciding who wins the NFC South.

Sunday Football (Late Game) ‚Äî New England Patriots at New York Jets

The Patriots have a path to the top seed in the AFC. In order for that potentiality to become reality, finding a way to beat the Jets on the road needs to take place. I have no concerns about their ability to do so. I don‚Äôt think this game will be close at all. I‚Äôve got New England winning on the road in a landslide.

Sunday Football (Early Game) ‚Äî Seattle Seahawks at Carolina Panthers

The Seahawks defied the odds and rallied late to defeat the Rams in Week 16, whilst the Panthers were able to defeat Tampa Bay. Both these teams want this game. Seattle winning would pretty much assure them the top seed in the NFC. A Panthers win would give them a shot at the NFC South title if the Buccaneers wind up losing. A lot is at stake in this one, but I think Seattle gets a huge road win.

The Rams would be eliminated from both the #1 seed and NFC West title race if the Seahawks beat the Panthers and the 49ers beat the Bears in Week 17. pic.twitter.com/5H1p6Zi0Ba

‚Äî Brian Nemhauser (@hawkblogger) December 23, 2025

Sunday Football (Late Game) ‚Äî New York Giants at Las Vegas Raiders

Sporting 2-13 records, the Giants and Raiders are the worst teams in their respective conferences. The loser of this game will have the upper hand relative to earning the #1 pick in the 2026 NFL Draft. But maybe something crazy happens and it ends in a tie. Who knows? I don‚Äôt really care. I‚Äôll just pick the Giants for the heck of it.

Sunday Football (Late Game) ‚Äî Philadelphia Eagles at Buffalo Bills

Both the Eagles and Bills have clinched playoff berths. Philadelphia won the NFC East and will get to host a playoff game. The Bills aren‚Äôt out of the AFC East race yet but need some help for that to happen. I ultimately expect the Patriots to take that division. Even so, I think the Bills beat the Eagles. It should be a fun matchup either way.

Sunday Night Football ‚Äî Chicago Bears at San Francisco 49ers

Boasting 11-4 records, the Bears and 49ers are also in the postseason. Each team has a slim path to the top seed in the NFC. What both of them have accomplished this year is impressive. I certainly didn‚Äôt have either of them securing 11 wins this season. This might be the most fun matchup of Week 17 and should be a great primetime game for all football fans to enjoy. I‚Äôm taking the 49ers in this one.

Monday Night Football ‚Äî Los Angeles Rams at Atlanta Falcons

The Rams definitely need to find a way to win this game after being stunned by the Seahawks in Week 16. Dropping that game plummeted their chances of being the NFC‚Äôs top seed. I‚Äôve got Los Angeles winning this one. And guess what? A victory will make the first-round pick they get from Atlanta better in the ‚Äò26 NFL Draft.

title: MotoGP circuit contracts: How long will each race remain on the calendar?
description: Find out which of MotoGP‚Äôs 22 circuits are secured by long-term contracts and which face an uncertain future...
fullText:
MotoGP‚Äôs calendar has expanded rapidly over the years, peaking at 22 grands prix in 2025. With the addition of sprints, riders are now required to contest a total of 44 races a year.

In many respects, MotoGP has followed Formula 1‚Äôs lead in recent years, not only in expanding its calendar but also in its approach to circuit agreements. Like F1, MotoGP is now increasingly signing long-term deals with promoters, providing greater stability to the championship.

As a result, many circuits - primarily those located in Europe - are already confirmed well into the next decade. At the other end of the spectrum, however, several venues currently have just one remaining race in 2026 before their contracts expire.

Below is an overview of MotoGP‚Äôs current circuit agreements and the known duration of each contract as of December 2025.

Despite serious doubts surrounding the future of the Thailand Grand Prix, the government successfully finalised a new contract with Dorna in November 2025. The five-year extension, added to the existing agreement that runs through 2026, ensures that MotoGP will continue racing at Buriram until 2031.

Thailand has become an important market for the championship since it debuted on the calendar in 2018.

MotoGP will return to Brazil in 2026 at the heavily-renovated Autodromo Internacional Ayrton Senna in Goiania. The deal was signed at the end of 2024 with Brazil Motorsport, the same company that organises the Formula 1 race at Sao Paulo, and covers five seasons through to 2030.

Brazil last hosted a MotoGP event under the Rio Grand Prix moniker in 2004.

MotoGP is set to race in the US until at least 2027 according to an agreement signed between Circuit of the Americas and the City of Austin. The Texan venue joined the MotoGP calendar in 2013, just under a year after it was constructed, as part of a 10-year agreement. That deal was reinforced in 2018 and is understood to run through the 2027 season. Since then, only the 2020 event had to be cancelled due to the pandemic. MotoGP itself has not issued formal confirmation of the contract‚Äôs duration.

MotoGP has a long-standing agreement with Lusail Circuit that was signed back in 2019, keeping the Qatar Grand Prix on the calendar until 2031. The track was built primarily for motorcycle racing and has been a staple on the MotoGP schedule since 2004. For much of its tenure, it held the slot for the season opener.

Jerez will remain on the MotoGP calendar into the next decade. The Spanish venue has been an ever-present fixture on the calendar since 1987, and even hosted two races in 2020 during COVID-19. The latest contract that was agreed ahead of the 2025 event in April runs through the end of 2031.

MotoGP also agreed a new deal with the organisers of the French Grand Prix in 2025. And as is the case with some other races, this is also a long-term contract extension covering the next six events until 2031. Le Mans has proven hugely popular with fans, with the 2025 race recording the largest attendance in the championship‚Äôs history.

Like several other European tracks, the Catalan GP has a safe future in MotoGP. A new agreement between Barcelona and Dorna was signed in February 2025, and will conclude in 2031. Barcelona has already held 35 grands prix since it debuted on the calendar in 1992. By the end of the new contract, that number would go up to 41.

Mugello will enter the final year of its current contract in 2026. The organisers had previously agreed a two-year extension with Dorna in 2023, covering the ‚Äò25 and ‚Äò26 races. The Ferrari-owned track has been the annual host of the Italian Grand Prix since 1994, having first staged a 500cc race in 1992. With the 2026 race approaching, discussions over a new contract are likely to follow.

MotoGP did not disclose the length of its contract with Balaton Park when it announced that Hungary will join the calendar from 2025. What‚Äôs clear is that, following its debut race this year, it will remain on the MotoGP map in 2026. Organisers were required to complete several upgrades to bring the venue up to top-level motorcycle racing standards. Balaton Park is only the second track in Hungary to stage MotoGP after Hungaroring played host to two races in the early 1990s.

After a four-year absence, the Czech Grand Prix made a successful return in 2025 at Brno. The agreement announced by the then-Czech Prime Minister covers five seasons until the end of 2029. Brno is one of the most iconic venues in the championship‚Äôs history, with its permanent layout first debuting on the premier class calendar in 1987. Earlier configurations of the circuit, incorporating public roads, had hosted grand prix racing for decades prior to that.

The historic Assen track will remain an integral part of MotoGP for years to come. An agreement with the Dutch GP organisers was struck in 2024, adding five years to the previous contract that ran until 2026. That means the TT Circuit, built back in 1955, will remain on the calendar until at least 2031.

As part of MotoGP‚Äôs strategy to secure long-term contracts with promoters, the championship has also inked a new deal with Sachsenring until 2031. This agreement also runs for five years on top of MotoGP‚Äôs existing arrangement with the circuit until 2026. The new deal is also significant because 2027 marks the 100th anniversary of the inaugural race on the public roads in Hohenstein-Ernstthal, where the Sachsenring was later built.

Silverstone‚Äôs contract with MotoGP is due to expire after 2026. It‚Äôs unclear when and if a new deal will be agreed. For now, the British Grand Prix has been moved back to a more traditional slot in August after the 2025 event was held in May and on the same weekend as the Monaco Grand Prix and the Indianapolis 500. Outside of the pandemic, Silverstone has been the host of the British GP every year since 2010, when it took over from Donington Park.

Aragon‚Äôs contract with MotoGP is also up for renewal after 2026. The Spanish track previously signed a new contract with Dorna in 2022 that stipulated three grands prix over a five-year period. However, the agreement was restructured in 2024, guaranteeing Motorland an annual place on the calendar until the end of 2026. Aragon first held a grand prix in 2010 and has since become a regular fixture on the calendar, with 2023 the only year the race didn‚Äôt take place.

Misano is another track that agreed a fresh deal with MotoGP in 2025. Already confirmed till 2026, the new contract ensures the race that runs under the San Marino GP banner will remain a part of the calendar until 2031. Several tracks in Italy have hosted the San Marino GP over the decades, but it has been held annually in Misano since the circuit‚Äôs comeback in 2007.

Austrian GP‚Äôs future on the MotoGP map is also secure, with the last deal - signed in 2024 - running until the end of 2030. It was a five-year extension on top of the existing deal, which had been due to expire after 2025. Spielberg joined the MotoGP calendar in 2016, a year before Austrian manufacturer KTM entered the championship.

2025 was a year of contract renewals for MotoGP and another track which the championship locked in for the long term is Motegi. As part of the deal, the Honda-owned track will remain on the calendar until 2030. Motegi first held a MotoGP event in 1999, but it was only in 2004 that it permanently replaced Suzuka as the venue for the Japanese GP.

Although there is still some uncertainty, it is understood that Mandalika signed a 10-year agreement with MotoGP when it joined the calendar for the first time in 2022. This means the Indonesian GP will continue to run until at least 2031. While MotoGP has not officially confirmed the duration of the deal, organisers have consistently indicated that the agreement is long-term.

The 2026 Australian GP will be the last race under the current contract. Melbourne‚Äôs MotoGP future has been a subject of intense speculation for some time, amid uncertainty over whether a new deal could be completed. Phillip Island first hosted a grand prix in 1989, but only became a regular on the calendar in 1997. Its picturesque surroundings and unique layout have made it a popular venue for MotoGP.

Sepang‚Äôs contract is set to expire after 2026, but organisers remain confident that a new deal could be agreed over the winter break, describing it as their priority. One of the first modern circuits built in Southeast Asia, Sepang took over hosting duties for the Malaysian Grand Prix in 1999 and has remained a popular venue with both local and international fans ever since.

Another race whose contract expires in 2026 is Portugal. Portimao was at risk of dropping off the calendar after 2024, but a new two-year deal was agreed that saw the event being repositioned near the end of the season, forming a double-header with the Valencia finale. With the Portuguese government signing a fresh contract with F1 in December 2025, it remains to be seen whether it will also reach terms with MotoGP.

Valencia struck a five-year contract extension at the start of 2025, just months after its 2024 event had to be cancelled due to severe flooding in the region. With the new deal, Circuit Ricardo Tormo will stay on the calendar until at least 2031. Valencia first joined the MotoGP calendar in 1999 and has hosted the season finale every year since 2002, with just one exception.

MotoGP has also announced that it will return to Argentina in 2027 at a renovated Autodromo Oscar y Juan Galvez. The track, located in the capital Buenos Aires, last hosted a MotoGP race in 1999. Although the exact duration of the deal hasn‚Äôt been disclosed, the track effectively replaces Termas de Rio Hondo, which dropped off the calendar after 2025.

Pedro Acosta: ‚ÄúForgetting about the championship‚Äù transformed my MotoGP form

Rain spoils debut of Honda‚Äôs 850cc engine in Sepang test

Carlos Ezpeleta: ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have enough space‚Äù for every circuit asking to host MotoGP

title: Commanders vs. Cowboys radio coverage: Station, channels, live streams to listen live to NFL Christmas broadcast
description: Everything you need to know about listening to the Commanders vs. Cowboys on Christmas.
fullText:
Commanders vs. Cowboys radio coverage: Station, channels, live streams to listen live to NFL Christmas broadcast originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Dallas Cowboys will travel to Maryland to face the Washington Commanders on Christmas Day.

Both these NFC East teams are eliminated from postseason contention. However, they'll be the opening act for the NFL on Christmas.

The Cowboys' season was a tale of two sides of the ball. The Dallas offense was one of the more exciting units in the entire league. With Dak Prescott playing at an elite level, throwing the ball to both CeeDee Lamb and George Pickens, it was thrilling to watch the Cowboys' offensive attack.

However, their defense was one of the worst in the NFL. It got so bad that Jerry Jones brought in some defensive assets to help the struggling unit. While it seemed to improve the defense's overall state, it was not enough to save their season.

As for the Commanders, it was an unlucky season to say the least. Every week it felt like another key player on their team was injured. Whether it was Jayden Daniels, Terry McLaurin, Austin Ekeler and the list goes on.

While neither team has anything to gain, there's always a level of effort for divisional games.

Here's how to listen to¬†Commanders vs. Cowboys on Christmas.

National radio channels:¬†SiriusXM¬†channel 225 (away), 226 (home)

Commanders radio channels: BIG 100 (WBIG-FM 100.3 FM)

Cowboys radio channel: 105.3 The Fan (KRLD-FM)

The Commanders vs. Cowboys game can be listened to on SiriusXM¬†on channels 225 (Cowboys), and 226 (Commanders)

Locally, fans in the Washington area can tune into BIG 100 (WBIG-FM 100.3 FM).¬†In Dallas, fans can listen on 105.3 The Fan¬†(KRLD-FM).

If you are a new subscriber to SiriusXM, you can get your first month for free.¬†Listen to every NFL game live, plus other sports like college football, MLB, NBA, NHL, NASCAR and more. Stay updated with all the news and analysis from SiriusXM NFL Radio and other sport-specific channels.

The Commanders and Cowboys will kick off at 1:00 p.m. on Dec. 25, one of three games on Christmas Day.

Ian Eagle (play-by-play), Nate Burleson and Matt Ryan (color commentators) will be on the call, with Sarah Walsh and Melanie Collins on the sidelines.
